content: hello my hot glue loving friends we're back for episode 9 of black magic crafts
and some good news our friend Steve is back with us after a paint eating
incident related suspension today we're going to continue on our nautical theme
that we started last episode I'm sure all of you have built your long boats
actually I know some of you built them immediately after the episode launched
like the next day I get sent this play this Mike Harris like the day after the
video came out made this awesome longbow template's man templates are they're
great anyway now that you have this badass ship some of the cools got to
happen your party is out on a nice relaxing cruise and all of a sudden the
boat is under attack by a giant octopus squid Kraken beast Cthulhu thing
whatever something with tentacles you need to make a set of these creepy
looking tentacles so this project it all started on somebody posted on the DM
Scotty Facebook group some photos of some octopus pens that they bought at
Dollar Tree now full disclosure this project does break one of my rules for
black magic craft tutorials that rule is that I don't use materials that you
aren't going to easily be able to get now I know I use a
lot of extruded polystyrene and some of you can't get that but it is something
available across the world in hardware stores whereas these are a very specific
toy from a specific store however they're just too perfect and also I
think it likely that you'll be able to find them if you have a Dollar Tree in
your city and I know most of you do because everyone on the Facebook group
is always talking about Dollar Tree now when these were posted online I thought
ah they won't have them at my Dollar Tree but you know what I checked and lo
and behold they did right at the front amongst all the crap by the tails
there's a bucket of different stupid pans and a whole bunch of them are these
technical ones so you're going to need to go out to a Dollar Tree and see if
you can find them however failing that this build can be done with basically
any kind of hollow octopus toy you can take these principles and use them on
with a different toy or even a different project basically what it comes down to
is we took a cheap crappy rubber toy put an armature and it made them solid and
painted them up without further ado let's build some tentacles alright first
you're going to need to make some armature so that you can have your
tentacles and various poses I use them 14 gauge electrical wire with the outer
sheathing removed and to avoid having the wire poked through the soft rubber I
coated the end of each one with a blob of hot glue next I take the wire and
feed it into the tentacle making sure that the end reaches the very tip you'll
need to fill these pieces with something to make them solid so that they can't
squish causing the paint to crack on the soft rubber I use great stuff expanding
foam it's important that you use the door and window variety as it has the
lowest expansion rate feed the spray foam tube right to the
tip of the tentacle and slowly and carefully fill with foam work your way
down to the bottom trying to avoid both over filling and leaving gaps it's a bit
tricky as the foam expands over time but you'll get the hang of it
give the foam a few hours to expand and cure once the foam is cured cut off all
the excess at this point you can also adjust the pose of each one by bending
the wire armature to base these I use some two-inch washers with some wax
paper underneath I fill in the hole of each washer with some hot glue making a
pile of glue big enough to attach the tentacle then using more hot glue add a
bit of texture around the edges to start building up the water to give the bases
a bit more realistic wave look I use some white acrylic latex caulking and
smear it over the surface and sculpt in some waves
using a craft stick or a wet finger to kind of pull up little wave crests let
the caulking cure for a few hours before spray bombing with black paint this is
one case where you do want to make sure you use spray paint rather than just
black acrylic craft paint it'll stick better to the rubber for the first coat
of color I use a vibrant dark purple and this could take you a few coats then
with a little bit of white add it to the purple I hit the tops of the suction
cups I then mix in some turquoise with my
purple to create a contrasting shade for the underside of the tentacles between
the suction cups after repeating the first few coats of paint on the
tentacles I put a coat of dark blue on the base water at this point they have a
rather cartoonish look so you want to tone it down a bit by doing several
coats with a black wash then using a lighter blue eye dry brush the crests of
the waves on the basis for the last bit of paint work I use a white to dry brush
the very tips of all the waves giving it that foamy water look I also pull some
of this paint up onto the lower part of the tentacles so it looks like the water
is actually splashing up around it in the final step is to give everything
several coats with a spray gloss varnish I used a brand called minnow ax but any
brand will do this will give everything a nice wet look and it will also help
protect the paint on the soft rubber from cracking and chipping by giving
everything a nice hard shell the finished pieces look great and I'm super
happy with the results they do have some text embossed on them that you can see
in this close-up but it's not really noticeable in the game table if you're
really concerned about it you could shave that off before starting the build
alright guys I hope you found this tutorial helpful if you did hit a like
on the video if you aren't already a subscriber go below hit subscribe we are
putting out awesome tutorials at the speed of moderately often but try to
always put a quality work so you won't be disappointed also if you want to head
on over to Facebook there's a black magic craft group there where I post
random stuff link is in the description until next time
